objtitle.title: *Christ Appearing to the Apostles After the Resurrection*

objinfo.printdate: c. 1804-05The characteristics of the color printing indicate that this impression is the first one printed c. 1804-05. The second impression in that printing session is *Christ Appearing to the Apostles After the Resurrection* in the Yale Center For British Art (Butlin 325).
objinfo.medium: planographic color printing with water color and pen and ink additions to the impression

provenance.note: Probably acquired by Blake's wife, Catherine, upon his death in 1827; acquired by Frederick Tatham, probably upon Mrs. Blake's death in 1831; sold Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, lot 186 (£2.10s. to the dealer H. Palser); William A. White by 1919; acquired from White's collection by the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach c. 1929 and sold to Lessing J. Rosenwald in 1930; given by Rosenwald to the National Gallery of Art, Washington, in 1945.

desc.objtitle: Christ Appearing to the Apostles after the Resurrection (National Gallery of Art), Object 1 (Butlin 326)

objnote.p: "Christ Appearing to the Apostles after the Resurrection" illustrates Luke 24:36-40. Christ stands in the midst of his followers and shows them his stigmata, but they are "terrified and affrighted." Blake shows the apostles bowing down before Christ, with at least one clasping his hands together in prayer.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In this scene, based on Luke 24:36-40, the risen Christ appears to his worshiping disciples, who kneel on either side of him. Christ stands at the center of the composition with his arms outstretched and palms out, exposing the stigmata in his hands; the wound in his left side is also visible. He strides forward with his left foot, also showing a wound. His head is bent to the right with eyes turned upward. Halo-like radiance surrounds his head and upper body; its light also illuminates the area above the disciples. Three figures bow to the right of Christ. In the foreground, a gowned, bearded disciple prostrates himself with his face, lower left arm, and left palm pressed to the ground. Behind the front-most figure kneels and bows a bearded figure with short, curly hair, arm bent upward, and palms together as if in prayer, his fingers interdigitated. The third figure from the front bends forward with his head down. His hair may be long. Four figures kneel to the left of Christ. The front-most figure, a partly nude male with short, curly hair, kneels and sits upright as he looks upward towards Christ. His arms are bent upward, and his hands are together as if in prayer, with mouth open. The next figure from the front bows deeply; his head and bent right arm appear below the hands of the front-most figure. He may be praying, with hands together. The third disciple from the front, who has curly hair, appears above the second figure. We see only the back and head of the final bowing disciple on the left. The background is not defined, but the reticulations of color printing below the figures might suggest low-growing vegetation.

component.illusobjdesc: The risen Christ stands at the center of the composition surrounded by worshiping disciples. He strides forward with his prominent left foot. The muscles of his left leg and prominent knee are clearly visible through his gown. Christ's arms are extended outward from his sides at 45 degrees, with palms out and fingers spread, revealing the stigmata on his palms. His gown is draped over his right shoulder, leaving the left side of his breast uncovered and exposing the wound on his left side. We can also see the wound in his left foot. His head is bent to his left and his eyes are raised. His hair is long and curly, and he is bearded. A halo-like radiant glow surrounds his head and upper body. His mouth may be slightly open; he may be speaking.

Three disciples kneel to the right of Christ. The front-most disciple, who is gowned, bearded, and has short, curly hair, bends his body sharply forward in a semi-prone or hunched-over position to prostrate himself in a deep bow at the feet of Christ. His face is pressed to the ground, as is his left palm; his left arm is bent upward at the elbow and rests on the ground. His posture suggests prayer. His open left eye looks down at the ground.

Three disciples kneel to the right of Christ. The second disciple from the front kneels and bends or hunches forward in a deep bow facing down and to the left. His left arm is apparently bent upward at the elbow. His hands are raised to his face and are together in prayer, with fingers interdigitated. His left eye looks down. He is gowned and has short, curly hair.

Three disciples kneel to the right of Christ. The third gowned disciple from the front kneels and bends or hunches forward in a deep bow with his head down in a posture suggestive of prayer. Only his back, shoulders, and the top of his head, with its long hair, are visible.

Four disciples kneel to the left of Christ. The front-most figure is a youthful male who sits upright with his legs bent beneath him in a kneeling posture. His arms are bent upward and his palms are together; this posture suggests prayer. With his head bent back and his right eye raised, he looks towards the risen Christ. His hair is short and curly, and a gown covers his lower body, leaving his shoulders and upper body bare. His mouth is open.

Four disciples kneel to the left of Christ. Immediately beneath and to the right of the front-most figure, the head and right arm of another disciple appear. Although the backs of the two middle figures on the left are not clearly differentiated, we probably also see something of his gowned back. His right arm is bent upward at the elbow and raised in front of his face. His partially visible hands may be together in a posture suggestive of prayer. His right eye looks downward.

Four disciples kneel to the left of Christ. The head of the third figure from the front is visible to the right of the hands of the front-most figure. Only his downward-bent head, which is covered with somewhat short, curly hair, is clearly visible, although we can probably also see his gowned back (not clearly differentiated from the back of the figure in front of him). He is most likely kneeling, like his companions, and hunched over, and may be praying like the other figures.

Four disciples kneel to the left of Christ. We see only the head (just right of the neck and chin of the front-most figure) and gowned back of the fourth figure from the front. Like his companions, he is probably kneeling and bent over in a deep bow to the right; he may be praying.
A halo-like radiance surrounds the head and upper body of Christ and suffuses downward above the heads of the disciples.
The background is not defined, but the reticulations of color printing on the ground below the figures might suggest low-growing vegetation such as grass, moss, or lichens.
